comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Pyrmont Bridge opened in 1902, replacing an earlier one - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2362655049/ . This is a pair with www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2362702929/ . The other shows the bridge open. But the puzzle is how did the photographer (Kerry) get so high? In a balloon?

comment.author: 35672655@N00
comment._content:
^he climbed the 200ft chimney of the pyrmont power station.
The first of the 3 stacks was erected in 1904.
2 more stacks (1908 & 1913) were even taller at 215ft high)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Thanks uminarampart - I applaud your extensive knowledge of tall buildings around Sydney. How did you get interested in that, and where do you find your information? Presumably you cannot climb a chimney stack when it is belching smoke, so this photo must be 1904 (whilst Anthony Hordern's New Palace Emporium was being built). I wonder if the photographer was Melvin Vaniman who was climbing all around Sydney in 1903-4. See www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4350240764/ . Or maybe a Kerry studios staffer who was trying to compete?

comment.author: 35672655@N00
comment._content: yes the chimney was just completed and not yet functioning. ideal time to take photos. same goes for the 200ft stack at the Rocks. view back at chimneys. photo tzaken from shorter chimney www.historicphotographs.com.au/images/H/previews/H180_p.jpg
